recipe_collection.title: Recipe Collection - UK Measurements
recipe_collection.description: All recipes have been converted from the original sources with measurements in UK units (grams, millilitres, Celsius).

recipes.name: Red Cabbage Slaw
method: Prepare vegetables: Thinly slice the red cabbage and cut the red onion into thin slivers.
Make dressing: In a large bowl, whisk together mayonnaise, apple cider vinegar, sugar, dried dill, celery seeds, salt, and black pepper.
Combine: Add the sliced cabbage and onion to the dressing and toss to combine thoroughly.
Serve: Can be served immediately or refrigerated until ready to serve.
notes: Storage: Keeps in the fridge for up to 4 days in an airtight container
Make-ahead: The slaw actually improves after sitting as flavours meld together
Texture tip: If liquid accumulates after a day or two, simply drain it off

recipes.name: Homemade Ciabatta Garlic Bread
method: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F).
Make herb oil: Add garlic, rosemary, oregano, and parsley to a small food processor. Blend while slowly drizzling in the olive oil through the top opening. Season with salt and pepper.
Prepare bread: Place ciabatta flat on cutting board and slice horizontally in half. Spread the herb-garlic oil evenly on both cut sides. Put halves back together.
First bake: Line a large baking tray with foil. Place bread on tray and cover completely with another sheet of foil, crimping edges tightly. Bake for 10 minutes.

Second bake: Remove from oven and uncover. Separate bread halves and place cut-side up on the tray. Sprinkle Parmesan evenly over both halves. Return to oven for another 10 minutes until edges are golden and cheese is lightly browned.
Serve: Cut into 2.5cm (1-inch) slices and serve immediately.
tips: Foil wrapping is crucial - it prevents garlic burning while creating a crispy outside and chewy inside
Use fresh garlic - avoid pre-minced jarred garlic which can be bitter
Freshly grate Parmesan for best flavour and texture
Alternative breads: French baguette or other rustic crusty breads work well

storage.room_temp: Wrap in foil, keeps for 2 days (don't refrigerate)
storage.freezer: Wrap in foil, store in freezer bag for up to 3 months
storage.reheat: Bake at 190°C (375°F) until hot and crispy

variations: Vegan version: Omit cheese or substitute with 1-2 tablespoons nutritional yeast

recipes.name: Financiers (French Tea Cakes)
recipes.notes_scaling: Recipe scaled x1.5 for 6 egg whites
equipment: Mini muffin tin(s) - you'll need 1.5 batches worth
method: Brown the butter: Melt butter in a small saucepan over medium heat. Continue cooking until it boils, turns golden brown, and smells nutty (about 8 minutes). Pour into a bowl and cool for 30 minutes. Keep all the dark bits - that's where the flavour is!
Prepare tin: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Lightly grease the wells of a mini muffin tin with softened butter.
Mix dry ingredients: In a large bowl, whisk together icing sugar, almond flour, plain flour, and salt.
Combine: Add the egg whites, vanilla extract, and cooled brown butter to the dry ingredients. Whisk until just combined. The batter will be thick.
Fill tins: Divide batter among the greased muffin cups, filling about three-quarters full. A piping bag makes this easier.
Bake: Bake for 15-20 minutes until edges are golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the centre comes out clean. Watch carefully near the end to avoid overbaking.
Cool: Let cool in the tin for 10 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
tips: Egg whites: Separate eggs when cold (easier), but use at room temperature
Don't overbake - this is the most common mistake leading to dry financiers
Measure flour accurately - use scales for best results
Optional flavours: Add a scant ½ teaspoon almond, lemon, or orange extract with the vanilla, or fold in citrus zest

storage.room_temp: Store in an airtight container for up to 2 days for crisp exterior (up to 1 week but texture softens)
storage.make_ahead: Batter can be stored in the fridge for up to 1 week
storage.freezing: Not recommended as texture becomes softer upon thawing

recipes.name: Torta della Nonna (Italian Custard Tart)

pastry_cream: Make the custard using egg yolks, sugar, flour and hot milk flavoured with lemon
Cook on the stove for about 5 minutes, stirring continuously until thickened
Cover with cling film directly on the surface to prevent a skin forming
pastry: Beat 3 eggs with sugar and sunflower oil
Gradually mix in flour until dough becomes too thick to stir
Turn onto work surface and knead by hand until smooth, elastic and no longer sticky
assembly: Oil and flour a 28cm round tin
Roll out half the pastry on floured parchment paper and place in the prepared tin as the base
Pour the cooled pastry cream over the base
Roll out remaining pastry and place on top
finishing: Dust generously with icing sugar before serving

notes: Can use butter (140g) instead of oil - if using butter, refrigerate dough wrapped in cling film for 30 minutes before rolling
Can use plant milk instead of dairy milk
Can substitute pine nuts with other nuts like almonds
Store under a glass dome or cake cover in a cool, dry place for several days

recipes.name: My Best Grilled Cheese Sandwich

ingredients.notes: for spreading on bread, or unsalted butter plus a pinch of salt

method: Butter the bread: Spread butter on BOTH sides of each slice of bread (yes, all 4 sides!).

Light toast: Heat a heavy-based frying pan over medium-low heat (no oil or butter needed). Place both slices of bread in the pan and lightly toast for 1 minute to warm through and create a light crust.
Add cheese: Flip one slice of bread, then pile on the cheddar cheese followed by the mozzarella. Place the other slice of bread on top with the hot toasted side in contact with the cheese.

Cook first side: Cook for 3 minutes until the bread is evenly golden and crisp, pressing down lightly with a spatula occasionally. If browning too quickly, remove from heat briefly and lower the temperature.
Flip and finish: Turn the sandwich over and cook the other side for 3 minutes until golden and the cheese is melted.
Serve: Transfer to a cutting board, cut in half decisively, admire the cheese pull, and devour immediately!
golden_rules: Use TWO types of cheese - mozzarella for stretch and melting quality, plus a flavoured cheese like vintage cheddar or gruyère
Cook in a pan on the stove - NOT a sandwich press! This gives you a superior golden, buttery crust
tips: Use sourdough instead of ordinary sandwich bread
Freshly grate your own cheese - pre-shredded cheese has anti-caking agents that prevent proper melting
Use salted butter - the salt makes all the difference!
Medium-low heat is key - gives time for cheese to melt without burning the bread
Heavy-based pan works best for even heat distribution

recipes.name: The Best Cinnamon Rolls

dough.amount: 1 large egg plus 1 large egg yolk

equipment: Stand mixer with dough hook (or mix by hand)

prepare_dough: Warm milk: Microwave milk for 45 seconds to 1 minute until it reaches 46°C (115°F) - should feel like warm bath water.

Mix wet ingredients: Place warmed milk in stand mixer bowl with paddle attachment. Sprinkle yeast on top. Add sugar, melted butter, egg, and egg yolk. Mix on medium speed for 30 seconds until well combined.
Add dry ingredients: Remove bowl from mixer and use a wooden spoon to stir in flour and salt until dough begins to form.

Knead: Attach dough hook. Mix on medium speed for 8-10 minutes until dough is soft and slightly sticky. If too sticky, add 1-3 tablespoons more flour. (Alternatively, knead by hand for 8-10 minutes on floured surface.)
First rise: Lightly grease a large bowl with olive oil. Place dough ball in bowl, cover with cling film and a warm towel. Let rise until doubled, 1-1½ hours.
assemble: Roll out: Generously flour work surface. Roll dough into a 25cm × 36cm (10" × 14") rectangle.
Add filling: Spread softened butter over dough, leaving 6mm (¼-inch) margin at one short edge. Mix brown sugar and cinnamon in small bowl. Sprinkle over butter and gently rub into the butter.

Roll up: Starting from short side without margin, tightly roll up dough. Seal edge by pinching dough. Place seam-side down. Cut 1.3cm (½-inch) off each end. Gently push ends inward to compact slightly.
Slice: Using dental floss or serrated knife, cut into 9 slices (about 2.5cm/1-inch each).
Second rise: Line 23cm (9-inch) tin with baking paper. Place rolls in tin. Cover with cling film and towel. Let rise until doubled and touching, 45 minutes to 1 hour.
bake: Bake: Remove cling film and towel. Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden brown on edges. Don't overbake - this keeps them soft in the middle. Cool for 10 minutes.
frosting: Make frosting: Beat cream cheese, icing sugar, butter, and vanilla on low speed for 30 seconds, then medium-high until smooth and fluffy, 1-2 minutes.
Frost: Spread frosting over warm rolls and serve.

tips: Don't overheat milk: Should be 46-49°C (105-115°F). If too hot, yeast will die.
Use room temperature butter for filling: Melted butter will leak out
Rub brown sugar into butter: Ensures it's well combined
Use bread flour: This is essential for fluffy, soft rolls - all-purpose won't give same results
Flour work surface and rolling pin to prevent sticking
recipes.make_ahead: After first rise and cutting rolls, place in lined tin, cover with cling film, and refrigerate overnight. In morning, bring to room temperature (30-45 minutes), then bake as directed.

storage.room_temp: Cover and store for 1-2 hours, then refrigerate
storage.refrigerator: Up to 5 days in airtight container
storage.freezer: Freeze after baking (before icing). Defrost, warm in oven at 180°C for 10-15 minutes, then ice

recipes.name: Overnight Pizza Dough
method: Mix dry ingredients: In a large bowl, combine the flour, salt, and yeast.
Add water: In small portions, add the cold water to the flour mixture. Stir with a wooden spoon until well combined.
Add olive oil: Add olive oil to the mixture and stir to combine.

Knead: Dust a flat work surface with whole wheat flour (or plain flour). Knead the dough with your hands until it turns elastic, approximately 8-10 minutes. Alternatively, use a stand mixer with dough hook on medium-low speed for 7-8 minutes.
Form ball: Shape the dough into a ball.
Overnight rise: Place the dough in a bowl and cover tightly with cling film. Leave to rise overnight in the refrigerator. Use within 3 days.
tips: Use very cold water: This is crucial for slowing the fermentation process during the overnight rise in the fridge
Use a stand mixer if available: Makes kneading much easier and faster (7-8 minutes on speed 2)
Dough texture: The dough should be slightly sticky but come together into a smooth, elastic ball. If too wet, add flour gradually
Use high-quality olive oil: Opt for 100% pure extra virgin olive oil for better flavour
Use high-quality flour: Higher protein content flour works best for better texture
Don't tightly pack flour: Loosely spoon flour into measuring cups and level off to avoid using too much
how_to_use: Rest at room temperature: Remove from fridge and let sit for 30 minutes before using
Divide: Cut into portions (2 or 3 pieces depending on pizza size desired)
Shape: Use your hands to stretch the dough into desired shape - NEVER use a rolling pin as it removes air and prevents bubbling
Top and bake: Add your toppings and bake at 220°C (425°F) for about 12 minutes or until golden brown

storage.refrigerator: Keep covered in bowl with cling film for up to 3 days
storage.freezer: Roll into a ball, wrap tightly in cling film, freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in fridge before using
storage.best_results: Dough develops better flavour after 2 days in the fridge

notes: The slow, cold fermentation creates a thin, delicate Northern Italian-style crust
Longer fermentation (24-48 hours) develops more flavour and creates a more airy, open crumb
The dough will rise slowly in the fridge - it may not double like traditional dough, and that's normal
If dough seems very wet during kneading, this is a higher-hydration dough. Add flour gradually as needed, but don't add too much or crust will be tough

recipes.name: Classic New York Cheesecake

crust.notes: from 12 whole crackers, or use digestive biscuits

filling.notes: at room temperature, use good quality like Philadelphia

equipment: Large roasting tin for water bath

prepare_crust: Preheat oven to 190°C (375°F), rack in lower middle position.
Wrap tin: Wrap springform tin with TWO large pieces of heavy-duty foil, covering underside and extending to the top with no seams on bottom or sides. Spray inside with nonstick cooking spray.
Make crust: In a medium bowl, combine graham cracker crumbs, melted butter, sugar, and salt. Stir until well combined.
Bake crust: Press crumbs into an even layer on bottom of tin. Bake for 10 minutes until set. Remove and set aside.
Reduce oven temperature to 160°C (325°F). Put kettle on to boil water.
make_filling: Beat cream cheese mixture: In electric mixer with paddle attachment, beat cream cheese, sugar, and flour on medium speed until just smooth, about 1 minute. Scrape bowl to ensure evenly combined.
Add flavourings: Add vanilla, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt; beat on low speed until just combined.
Add eggs: Add eggs one at a time on low speed, mixing until incorporated and scraping bowl as necessary.
Add sour cream: Mix in sour cream until batter is uniform. Don't over-mix.
bake: Assemble: Pour batter over baked crust. Place springform tin in large roasting tin.
Create water bath: Pour boiling water into roasting tin to come about 2.5cm (1 inch) up sides of springform tin.

Bake: Bake for 1 hour 30 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes, until cake is just set. It should not look liquid but will wobble slightly when gently nudged. If top looks too golden near end, cover loosely with foil.
cool_and_chill: Cool in water bath: Remove roasting tin from oven and place on wire rack. Cool cheesecake in water bath until water is just warm, about 45 minutes.
Remove from bath: Remove springform tin from water bath and discard foil. If necessary, run thin knife around edge to prevent sticking and cracking.
Refrigerate: Cover with cling film and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or overnight.
serve: Remove sides of springform tin. Serve from base or transfer to serving plate using large spatulas. Slice with sharp knife, wiping clean between slices.

tips: Room temperature cream cheese is essential - prevents lumps
Don't over-mix - mix until just combined to prevent incorporating too much air
Flour is the secret - helps prevent cracking and makes filling lighter
Water bath is crucial - ensures even, gentle baking and prevents cracks
Use heavy-duty 45cm (18-inch) foil - NO seams on bottom or sides or water will leak in
Don't overbake - cake should wobble slightly in centre when done
Cool gradually - in water bath first, then room temperature, then fridge

storage.make_ahead: Can be made and kept covered in fridge for up to 2 days
storage.freezer: Freeze for up to 3 months. Wrap tightly after briefly freezing unwrapped to firm up. Thaw overnight in fridge.

serving_suggestions: Serve with berry sauce on the side
alternative_wrapping: Place springform tin inside a larger cake tin to avoid using foil
Purchase a silicone wrap designed for springform tins
If condensation gets in despite wrapping, remove sides of tin before refrigerating to let crust dry out
